acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 6,700mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2001-38 (i) (2002)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category D by EPA (1993) and Group 3 by IARC (1987).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: May cause long lasting harmful effects to aquatic life
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although L(E) C50 <=100 mg/L data existed, since it was metal and the behavior in the water was unknown, it classified into Category 4.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classification not possible, because of the unidentified configuration and the absence of data. The substance is combustible according to ICSC (2004) and, as far as metals are concerned, the finer the particles, the more dangerous they are, according to Sax (11th, 2004). Metal powder (combustibles, and excluding those with specific product names) is classified into Division 4.1, Packing Group II and III (UN#3089), by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing no oxygen and halogen

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on reproduction and pups, described in EHC 58 (1986) (though no data on parental toxicity are available).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Insufficient data available, though CERI Hazard Data 2001-39(i)(2002)reports epidemiological evidence of human exposure: "irritating." to labor exposed high level of Selenium for a short time.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Classified as metalloids. Selenium reacts with water at 50degC, with the evolution of selenious acid and flammable hydrogen, according to  ICSC (2004). However, classification is not possible due to lack of data on the maximum generation rate of hydrogen gas at ambient temperature.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, respiratory system, liver)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "peripheral nerve conduction velocity, peripheral nerve paralysis, neurological symptoms including pain and abnormal reflex, consciousness disorder, spasm, paralysis, changes in motor activity" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-39 (i) (2002)) and "chronic bronchitis or moderate pulmonary emphysema" (EHC 58 (1986)), and the evidence from animal studies including "cirrhosis" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-39 (i) (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (liver).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (nervous system, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence including "vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, numbness of hands, abnormal menstrual bleeding and abnormal dehairing" (HSDB (1998)), and the evidence from animal studies including "pneumonitis" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-39 (i) (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1 (respiratory organs)

Note: As for acute toxicity of inorganic selenium compounds, "clinical findings include vomiting, diarrhea, laboured breathing, weakness, unstable gait and coma, while histological findings include pulmonary edema, necrosis of the liver, degeneration of the skeletal muscles, hydropic degeneration of renal tubules, swelling and rupture of the myocardial mitochondria" (PATTY (4th, 2000)).
